meta.title: Building This Portfolio
meta.subtitle: A meta case study on creating a role-agnostic portfolio
meta.teaser: How I designed a format-based navigation system to present work across Content Design, Technical Writing, and Narrative roles.

project.summary: This case study explores the decisions behind building this portfolio site. As a multidisciplinary writer spanning Content Design, Technical Writing, and Narrative/Game Writing, I needed a portfolio structure that could adapt to different hiring contexts without pigeonholing my work into a single specialty.

section.heading: Challenge
section.body:
[Placeholder - Nick to write]

Creating a role-agnostic portfolio for a multidisciplinary writer. The challenge was presenting work that spans Content Design, Technical Writing, and Narrative/Game Design without forcing visitors to choose a professional identity before exploring.

section.heading: Information Architecture Decisions
section.body:
[Placeholder - Nick to write]

Why format-based taxonomy (Case Studies vs. Individual Samples) over role-based categories. The distinction is about depth and presentation style, not professional specialty:

  • Case Studies: Deep dives into content decisions based on specific objectives, showcasing cross-collaboration and strategic thinking
  • Individual Samples: Focused pieces demonstrating craft in a particular format without full project context

How the tag system works for discovery while categories handle wayfinding:

  • 18 tags across 4 categories for filtering (desktop only)
  • Category landing pages for mobile users who don't have desktop tag filters
  • localStorage for nav state persistence
